item.title: Afghanistan: US tells citizens to avoid Kabul airport
item.description: The warning comes amid continued chaos outside the airport, with reports of a deadly crush.

item.title: Afghanistan: Labour demands urgent action over evacuation crisis
item.description: People being beaten, shot at or raped while trying to secure documentation in Kabul, Lisa Nandy says.

item.title: Covid: Australian police clash with anti-lockdown protesters
item.description: Hundreds of people are arrested after rallies against lockdown measures in Melbourne and Sydney.

item.title: The Hundred: Southern Brave beat Birmingham Phoenix to win men's title
item.description: Southern Brave are crowned the first men's Hundred champions after beating Birmingham Phoenix by 32 runs in an action-packed Lord's final.

item.title: Westminster double murder: Police say wanted man knew victims
item.description: Detectives want to trace Lee Peacock after two people were found dead with knife injuries in London.

item.title: Hillsborough: Minute's applause for 97th victim
item.description: Liverpool fans chanted "Justice for the 97" after the death of Andrew Devine who was hurt in the 1989 crush.

item.title: R. Kelly aide says he paid bribe for singer to marry Aaliyah
item.description: An ex-tour manager for the singer testifies that he obtained a fake ID for then 15-year-old Aaliyah.

item.title: Covid: CO2 monitors pledged to aid school ventilation
item.description: Schools in England are to be given CO2 monitors to as part of plans to limit the spread of Covid.

item.title: Manchester City 5-0 Norwich City: Jack Grealish scores on home debut for Premier League champions
item.description: Manchester City's £100m man Jack Grealish scores on his home debut as the reigning Premier League champions thrash Norwich.

item.title: Puppy smuggling: Rise in cases prompts new welfare rules
item.description: Ministers want to stop the "grim trade" in criminals profiting from the rise in demand for pets.

item.title: Ever Given: Cargo ship returns through Suez Canal it blocked
item.description: Global trade was disrupted in March when the massive container ship became stuck in the waterway.

item.title: Only Fools and Horses garage door sold to TV fan
item.description: The garage door was sold to a TV memorabilia fan who hopes to get it displayed in a museum.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: Blair's attack on US exit, and UN aid warning
item.description: Former UK prime minister Tony Blair's comments on Afghanistan make many of Sunday's front pages.

item.title: Nigeria's royal wedding: Private jets, glitz and glamour
item.description: President Buhari's son marries the daughter of a religious leader in one of Nigeria's events of the year.

item.title: The West End star who worked as carer during lockdown
item.description: As theatres reopen, actors like Stephen Beckett have been swapping their lockdown jobs for their place on the stage once more.

item.title: Mission: Impossible films Derbyshire quarry train crash
item.description: Crews had been building the set for months and the nearby village had seen lorry-loads of props appearing.

item.title: Banksy: Rusty old boat a 'godsend' destined for museum
item.description: The small metal "boat" under a painting of three children could become a museum piece.

item.title: 'I play carrom with my feet'
item.description: Twenty-three-year-old Harshad Gothankar was born without arms, but he is now a state carrom champion.

item.title: Week in pictures: 14 - 20 August 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images from all over the globe, taken this week.

item.title: Covid cases: This summer compared with last
item.description: Case numbers are 30 times higher than at the same point last year - where might we be heading next?

item.title: Red phone box stolen from Cheshire garden in broad daylight
item.description: Three men used a digger to steal the phone box, belonging to Chelford Parish Council, police say.

item.title: Biden's week of blame and tumult after Kabul fall
item.description: How the fall of Kabul stunned the Biden administration and spawned the worst week of his presidency.

item.title: The pregnant woman who caught a serial voyeur masseur
item.description: How a suspicious-looking alarm clock led to the downfall of a masseur who was spying on his clients.

item.title: Woke: Compliment or criticism, it is now fuelling the culture wars
item.description: The surprising history of a term increasingly thrown around in UK political debate.

item.title: OnlyFans porn ban a 'kick in the teeth' for creators
item.description: Content creators aren't pleased about the site's decision to ban explicit content from October.

item.title: Computer Space and beyond: 50 years of gaming
item.description: From an arcade game to a multi-billion pound industry, the BBC charts the ups and downs of video games.

item.title: LGBT in Afghanistan: 'I could be killed on the spot'
item.description: A gay student from Kabul tells Newsbeat how life has changed under the Taliban.

item.title: Clive Myrie: Becoming host of Mastermind is a big, big job
item.description: The journalist may be feeling jittery about his new role but hopes it will reveal his lighter side.

item.title: The Hundred final - Southern Brave beat Birmingham Phoenix to win men's title
item.description: Watch as Southern Brave are crowned the first men's Hundred champions after beating Birmingham Phoenix by 32 runs in an action-packed Lord's final.

item.title: 'It's like going 10 to 15 years backwards' - Klopp wants refereeing rethink after win over Burnley
item.description: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp said "it's like we're going 10 to 15 years backwards" as he called on the Premier League to protect players.

item.title: Inspired Invincibles crush Brave to win women's Hundred
item.description: Oval Invincibles storm to an emphatic 48-run victory over favourites Southern Brave to become the first women's Hundred champions on a historic afternoon at Lord's.

item.title: 10.54 - Thompson-Herah runs second-fastest women's 100m of all time
item.description: Olympic champion Elaine Thompson-Herah runs the second fastest time in women's 100m history as she clocks 10.54 seconds in Eugene.

item.title: Scottish amateur Duncan moves into contention at Women's Open - highlights & report
item.description: Scottish amateur Louise Duncan enthrals the Carnoustie crowd with a four-under 68 which moves her into contention on day three of the Women's Open.

item.title: Fast, fierce, fantastic - emotions run high as Leeds' fans long wait for live Premier League action ends
item.description: It has been 17 years since Elland Road was full for a Premier League game - and Leeds fans relished the chance to cheer on their team on an emotional day.

item.title: Match of the Day analysis: How Danny Ings scored his 'fabulous' bicycle kick for Aston Villa
item.description: Match of the Day's Gary Lineker, Jermaine Jenas and Danny Murphy analyse Danny Ings' "fabulous" bicycle kick for Aston Villa in their 2-0 win over Newcastle United.

item.title: Afghanistan: The desperate scramble to escape
item.description: The BBC witnesses scenes of chaos and panic as thousands still crowd Kabul's airport.

item.title: Afghan crisis: Russia plans for new era with Taliban rule
item.description: While Western governments raced to get their people out, Russia appears unfazed by the takeover.

item.title: Family of American taken by Taliban beg for return
item.description: Mark Frerichs, 59, one of the last Americans kidnapped by the Taliban, is stuck in Afghanistan.

item.title: How Afghanistan's media is changing under Taliban rule
item.description: The Taliban are currently on a media offensive but does their rhetoric match what’s happening on the ground?

item.title: 'They will kill me': Desperate Afghans seek way out after Taliban takeover
item.description: Many Afghans are desperate to escape after the Taliban takeover. Some fear there is no way out.

item.title: Afghanistan: Tears and applause as UK appeal helps refugees
item.description: People in Chapel-en-le-Frith in the Peak District collected more than 1,000 bags of donations in 48 hours.

item.title: The treacherous road to Kabul's airport
item.description: As thousands try to flee Afghanistan, the main route to the capital's airport has become treacherous.

item.title: Facebook moves to protect Afghan users' accounts amid Taliban takeover
item.description: The tech giant says it wants to reassure people worried about being tracked down by the Taliban.

item.title: Covid: How effective is the vaccine and do I need a booster?
item.description: All over-16s can get the Covid vaccine and boosters are expected to be rolled out from September.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: What are the holiday rules for travel to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: A traffic light system is in place setting out rules for entering the UK

item.title: Covid passport: How to prove your vaccine status with the NHS Covid Pass
item.description: Fully vaccinated adults are able to avoid self-isolation after contact with someone with Covid.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in other parts of the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Medical teams around the world are learning which medicines work best against Covid.

item.title: Michael Knighton: The man who could have bought Man Utd for £10m but walked away
item.description: In August 1989, Michael Knighton celebrated his Manchester United takeover deal at Old Trafford. But the plotting against him had just begun.

item.title: India's living dead: 'They stared at me like I was a ghost'
item.description: If you're dead you can't own land - so if someone obtains your death certificate you could lose everything.

item.title: Peter Karlsson: The painful verdict on Swedish ice hockey player's 1995 killing
item.description: Peter Karlsson was stabbed to death in the street. His killer said he was protecting himself - via the so-called 'gay panic' defence.

item.title: 'How I found out my dad was a best-selling sex writer'
item.description: Sara Faith Alterman was always close to her father. Then she learned he was concealing a secret.
